history.text: I really enjoyed this film- I thought Leonardo DiCaprio did a great job as the lead actor. I also thought that the plot of the movie was very unique and gave an interesting point of view into stock trading.
It seems Scorsese made a picture that showed Wall Street in a negative light, wouldn't you say?
I guess it depends on your point of view. I could definitely see that. But I think the movie tends to glorify the lifestyle as well at times.
How did you feel about the supporting cast?
Leo usually does a great job. I thought he captured the recklessness of his character.
I like Jonah Hill, but I'm not very familiar with the other actors.
I agree. It seems the reviews on the movie were somewhat mixed, though. It did not seem to do very well critically.
How many stars would you give it?
I would say four out of five...it wasn't perfect, but I think it was better than the average reviews it received.
Are you a DiCaprio fan?
Yes, I really like his work. He tends to do well in any lead that he's placed in.
The language turned me off, but I suppose it was realistic.
Could you see another actor doing a better job?
Yes. I think the penny stocks scene was important to setting up his personality. That he was willing to do anything to make money throughout the movie.

I'm not sure that I could, but there are many talented actors out there, so it's always a possibility
.
He seemed like a desperate person, constantly under stress and afraid of failure.
Do you know anyone who works on Wall Street?
Not personally, no. That would be an interesting insight into how this film contrasts with real world figures, though. What about you?
No, no Wall Street connection here. I actually pitied the Jordan character because he seemed to have no soul. Just greed.
Yes, I think that was clearly evident throughout the film.
If we can believe some reports, most investors are that way. It's all about greed and power.
At least the big-time investors...

The scamming scene exemplifies that as well... he brought in other desperate people to work for him in order to take money from other individuals by illegal means. Though it was an entertaining part of the film watching the FBI and SEC try to take him down.
He took great risks, didn't he? Personally and professionally.
And he easily found others to go along with him.
Yes, and I think it all caught up with him in the end. It was interesting watching his character try to dodge danger throughout the film
What do you know about the REAL Jordan, if anything?

The FBI scene again really demonstrated his character, or lack thereof. He's trying to bend the rules while escaping without consequence. Though at least there was some level of decency in trying to keep his friend from incriminating himself, though maybe there were selfish motives for that as well
I'm not sure... it seems like everything is focused on his lavish lifestyle throughout the film. Maybe that is the real him.
You 've got to give him credit for good instincts and knowledge.
I suppose so, even if his morals were questionable.
Which would you rather have? Money or a peaceful soul?
I think you have to find the balance of the two. Make enough to get by, but don't sell your morals or who you are as a person in order to get more.
Rob Reiner has come such a long way since his meathead days!

uid2response.feedback: I've watched SOME of the movie. The language turned me off.
